head.title: Ni0.67Fe0.33 Hydroxide Incorporated with Oxalate for Highly Efficient Oxygen Evolution Reaction | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Ni0.67Fe0.33 Hydroxide Incorporated with Oxalate for Highly Efficient Oxygen Evolution Reaction

As the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) imposes a high energy barrier during electrochemical water splitting, designing highly efficient, stable, and cost-effective electrocatalysts for OERs is an ongoing challenge. In this study, we present a facile approach to prepare villi-shaped Ni–Fe hydroxides incorporated with oxalate derived from Ni–Fe oxalate through the in situ precipitation growth and subsequent immersion in an alkaline solution. The electrode with an optimized Ni–Fe ratio improves the OER kinetics, on which the electronic structure of the active site is adjusted based on a mutual effect between the adjacent nickel and iron atoms. The OER performance was significantly better than that of monometallic Ni(OH)2 and pristine Ni foam, with a low overpotential of 277 mV at 100 mA cm–2 and excellent stability. The enhanced OER performance is ascribed to the advanced intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of the electrode as a result of the synergetic effect of optimized Ni–Fe ratio mixing at the atomic level which leads to an increased surface area, a high number of active sites, and a reduced charge transfer resistivity.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p:
As the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) imposes a high energy barrier during electrochemical water splitting, designing highly efficient, stable, and cost-effective electrocatalysts for OERs is an ongoing challenge. In this study, we present a facile approach to prepare villi-shaped Ni–Fe hydroxides incorporated with oxalate derived from Ni–Fe oxalate through the
in situ
precipitation growth and subsequent immersion in an alkaline solution. The electrode with an optimized Ni–Fe ratio improves the OER kinetics, on which the electronic structure of the active site is adjusted based on a mutual effect between the adjacent nickel and iron atoms. The OER performance was significantly better than that of monometallic Ni(OH)
2
and pristine Ni foam, with a low overpotential of 277 mV at 100 mA cm
–2
and excellent stability. The enhanced OER performance is ascribed to the advanced intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of the electrode as a result of the synergetic effect of optimized Ni–Fe ratio mixing at the atomic level which leads to an increased surface area, a high number of active sites, and a reduced charge transfer resistivity.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
With the transition of a large part of society’s energy demand to non-fossil fuels, electrochemical water splitting is considered to be a promising process for the production of hydrogen as an eco-friendly energy source with an ultrahigh gravimetric energy density.
(1−4)
In electrochemical water splitting consisting of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), a significant advance has been made in the development of high-efficiency non-noble metal-based HER catalysts that generally maintain the overpotentials around or below 150 mV at a nominal current density of 10 mA cm
–2
.
(5,6)
In comparison to the relatively simple HER that involves only a two-electron-transfer process, the OER has several reaction barriers, which are ascribed to a four-electron-transfer process and an oxygen–oxygen bond formation. This leads to a large overpotential of close to or greater than 300 mV at a nominal current density of 10 mA cm
–2
, which drives the reaction at a practical rate.
(7,8)
Therefore, the construction of efficient, stable, and non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts for OER can accelerate the overall efficiency of electrochemical water splitting.
(9,10)

Although noble metal-based electrocatalysts, including IrO
2
and RuO
2
, have been proven to be the principal materials with the lowest overpotential for OERs, drawbacks such as high cost, intrinsic scarcity, and inferior stability at high anodic potentials are still present for the large-scale industry. In this regard, a great demand exists for the investigation of alternative catalysts based on earth-abundant elements.
(11,12)
In an alkaline environment, the first-row transition metal-based electrocatalysts exhibit a high OER activity, presumably due to the same edge-sharing MO
6
structure.
(13,14)
In particular, Ni–Fe-based electrocatalysts with unique three-dimensional electronic structures have been investigated owing to their suitable chemical bond strength with catalytic reaction intermediates.
(10,15)
The fabrication of optimal contents of Ni and Fe blended at the atomic level is expected to be beneficial for achieving a low overpotential for OER. In such a case, a strong d–d-inter-metallic bonding exists between the intermetallic phases, resulting in a weaker intermediate adsorptive bond in the rate-determining step. Furthermore, the combination of Ni and Fe has the advantage of multiple oxidation states in the operating potential range.
(16)
In a recent study, Cao et al. reported the fabrication of Ni–Fe oxalate-based OER catalysts based on solid solutions between the nickel and iron oxalates in the presence of reductive oxalate anions. The as-prepared electrode delivered a current density of 50 mA cm
–2
at an ultralow overpotential of 203 mV owing to the mutual effect of proximate Ni and Fe at the atomic level and the unique structure that promoted mass diffusion. However, as solvothermal synthesis is applied to obtain the Ni–Fe oxalate, the large amount of energy consumption and long reaction time are still the main drawbacks.
(17)

Herein, we present a facile process to synthesize an Ni–Fe oxalate on Ni foam through an
in situ
precipitation-induced growth using an oxalic acid solution with Fe
3+
ions as a precursor for 90 min at room temperature (25 °C) without the provision of the external energy consumption. Additionally, as the as-prepared Ni–Fe oxalate is easily converted into villi-shaped Ni–Fe hydroxide nanowires through a self-templating process in an alkaline solution for 5 min, it has a large number of active sites that can improve the OER performance because of their high porosity and large surface area. Remarkably, the optimized Ni–Fe hydroxide electrode derived from the Ni–Fe oxalate exhibited a low overpotential of 277 mV at 100 mA cm
–2
with an excellent stability for 100 h. The effect of Fe
3+
concentration on the ratio of Ni to Fe and the corresponding electrochemical properties are further investigated and discussed.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All chemicals, including the Ni foams (thickness: 1.6 mm, area density: 346 mg cm
–2
, MTI Korea, Korea), FeCl
3
(98%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), C
2
H
2
O
4
(98%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA), ethanol (99.9%, Samchun Chemical, Korea), and KOH (85%, Duksan Pure Chemical, Korea) were purchased from commercial suppliers.

div.h3: 2.2. Synthesis of Ni–Fe Oxalate and Its Self-Template Conversion to Ni–Fe Hydroxide
div.div:
Ni foam (3 × 2 cm
2
) was sonicated in 1 M HCl solution, ethanol, and deionized water for 20 min to remove the native oxide layer and contaminants. To obtain the Ni–Fe oxalate on the Ni foam, the pretreated Ni foam was immersed in 1 M oxalic acid solution (ethanol/water 95:5 v/v) with different concentrations of FeCl
3
, ranging from 2.5 to 30 mM for 90 min at room temperature. Subsequently, the Ni foam covered with a pale yellow layer of Ni–Fe oxalate was removed from the solution, rinsed several times with ethanol, and dried in air. To convert the Ni–Fe oxalate with different ratios of Ni and Fe to Ni–Fe hydroxide, the obtained Ni–Fe oxalate samples were immersed in 1 M KOH solution for 5 min at room temperature. For comparison, the Ni oxalate was synthesized using a 1 M oxalic acid solution without the addition of FeCl
3
under identical experimental conditions.
(18)

The morphologies and chemical compositions of the as-prepared Ni–Fe oxalate samples were observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (4300S, Hitachi), which was equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. The crystal structure of the samples was analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku D/max-RB) with Cu Kα
1
radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). XRD analysis was performed after scratching the prepared material from the Ni foam in order to avoid the peaks originated from substrate. To determine the chemical states of the samples, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, VG ESCALAB 220i-XL spectrometer, Fisons) using an Al Kα X-ray source was employed. A Fourier transform-infrared vacuum spectrometer (FT-IR, Bruker VERTEX 80V) was employed to reveal the chemical composition of the nanostructures on the Ni foam.

KOH used in an OER experiment was purified as reported elsewhere.
(19)
In brief, 2 g of Ni(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O (99.999%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA) was dissolved in 4 mL of deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm) in a polypropylene (PP) centrifuge tube which was washed with sulfuric acid prior to use. Then, 20 mL of 1 M KOH (99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich, USA) solution was added to precipitate Ni(OH)
2
. The mixture was shaken for 30 min and centrifuged, and the supernatant was decanted. The obtained Ni(OH)
2
was washed three times with 20 mL of deionized water and 2 mL of 1 M KOH solution by redispersing, centrifuging, and decanting the supernatant. Finally, after adding 50 mL of 1 M KOH, Ni(OH)
2
was redispersed by shaking for at least 10 min, followed by 3 h of resting. The mixture was then centrifuged, and the purified KOH was decanted into a PP centrifuge tube for storage.

All electrochemical analyses were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (PGSTAT302N Autolab, Metrohm) at room temperature using a three-electrode system consisting of the prepared Ni–Fe-based electrocatalysts on the Ni foam (1 × 1 cm
2
) as the working electrode, a graphite as the counter electrode, and a Hg/HgO (1 M NaOH) electrode as the reference. All potentials in this study were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to
eq 1
.
(1)

Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted in purified 1 M KOH (pH = 14.0) electrolyte solution using a polytetrafluoroethylene beaker washed with sulfuric acid prior to use at a scan rate of 5 mV s
–1
. Tafel slopes were calculated from the corresponding LSV curves. The long-term stability test was measured by chronopotentiometry at a constant current density of 100 mA cm
–2
for 100 h. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded with an amplitude of 5 mV over a frequency ranging from 0.1 to 1 MHz. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) was obtained by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at different scan rates from 10 to 100 mV s
–1
in a potential window between 0.94 and 1.04 V (
vs
RHE). All the curves in this study were reported with a 90% iR compensation, which was obtained using
R
s
obtained via the impedance analysis corresponding to each sample.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Synthesis and Characterization of the Ni–Fe Oxalate
div.div:
When metals have a more negative standard reduction potential than hydrogen, their cations are readily released into the solution through a redox reaction with hydrogen ions to form metal oxalates by simultaneous dissolution and precipitation, called
in situ
precipitation-induced growth in aqueous or organic-based oxalic acid solutions.
(18,20−23)
As shown in
Figure S1
, because the standard reduction potential of Ni
2+
/Ni [−0.26 V
vs
standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)] has a more negative potential than that of hydrogen, Ni
2+
is gradually released from the Ni foam substrate to form the Ni oxalate nanosheets on the Ni foam surface through the simple integration of Ni
2+
and C
2
O
4
2–
at room temperature (
eqs 2
and
3
).
(18)
The diffraction peaks of the Ni oxalate can be indexed to orthorhombic NiC
2
O
4
·2H
2
O (JCPDS 25-0581).
(2)
(3)

Subsequently, iron chloride as an Fe precursor was additionally added to the oxalic acid solution to synthesize the Ni–Fe oxalate, wherein Ni and Fe are mixed at the atomic level. Notably, we found that when FeCl
2
was used as an additive, the precipitation reaction occurred instantly without providing time for the elution of Ni
2+
from the Ni substrate due to the high reactivity between Fe
2+
and C
2
O
4
2–
(see
Figure S2
). Conversely, when the precursor was FeCl
3
, Fe
3+
acted as an oxidizing agent similar to hydrogen, thereby dissolving Ni
2+
in the Ni substrate through a redox reaction.
(24,25)
Subsequently, this was converted into Fe
2+
by itself (
eq 4
) because the standard reduction potential of Fe
3+
/Fe
2+
(0.77 V
vs
SHE) was more positive compared to that of Ni
2+
/Ni (−0.26 V
vs
SHE).
(12,26)
Therefore, both Ni
2+
ions dissolved from Ni foam and Fe
2+
ions converted from Fe
3+
react with C
2
O
4
2–
to form homogeneous atomic-level blended Ni–Fe oxalate compounds (
eq 5
), as illustrated in
Scheme 1
. The prepared samples are denoted as NiFeC
2
O
4
-
Z
, where
Z
represents the Fe
3+
concentration.
(4)
(5)

Scheme 1. Schematic Illustration for the Synthesis of Villi-Shaped NiFe(OH)
x

The SEM images and photographs of NiFeC
2
O
4
-
Z
(
Z
= 2.5, 5, 7, 10, 20, and 30) samples are shown in
Figure
1
. It is observed that an increase in the Fe
3+
concentration transformed the morphology of the Ni–Fe oxalate nanostructures from nanosheets into needle-shaped nanowires with an average diameter of 100 nm. This distinct morphological alteration is attributed to the anisotropic growth occurring above a certain ratio of nickel and iron cations.
(27,28)
Furthermore, the large scale of the sample (4 × 15 cm
2
) could easily be obtained under the same conditions, showing uniform nanowire morphologies over the entire area (
Figure
1
g). EDX elemental mapping images of NiFeC
2
O
4
-10 indicate that Ni–Fe oxalate nanostructures were uniformly formed on the Ni foam surface with an even distribution of Ni and Fe components (
Figure S3
).

div.h3: 3.2. Conversion to Ni–Fe Hydroxide Incorporated with Oxalate
div.div:
The as-synthesized Ni–Fe oxalate (NiFeC
2
O
4
-
Z
) was easily converted into Ni–Fe hydroxide (denoted as NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
) through a self-templated conversion process by immersing the samples in alkaline media for a short time.
Figure
3
a shows the XRD patterns of NiFeC
2
O
4
-10 before and after immersion in the 1 M KOH solution. After immersing the sample, the peaks of the NiC
2
O
4
·
x
H
2
O and FeC
2
O
4
·
x
H
2
O disappeared, while new peaks corresponding to (002), (110), (111), (200), (103), and (300) planes of Ni(OH)
2
appeared at 23.8, 33.7, 35.2, 39.0, 41.2, and 59.6°, respectively (JCPDS no. 22-0444). Additionally, the FT-IR analysis was conducted to confirm the conversion of Ni–Fe oxalate to Ni–Fe hydroxide (
Figure
3
b). For NiFeC
2
O
4
-10, peaks at 3392, 1620, 1357, 1315, 823, and 486 cm
–1
were detected, corresponding to ν(H
2
O), asymmetric ν(C═O), asymmetric ν(C–O), asymmetric δ(O–C–O), γ(C–O), and symmetric δ(O–C–O), respectively.
(31−33)
However, for NiFe(OH)
x
-10, the peaks were observed at 3645, 3420, 1640, and 633 cm
–1
, corresponding to the ν(O–H), ν(H
2
O) stretching of the OH group, HOH bending, and water libration motion, respectively.
(31−33)
The appearance of the asymmetric ν(C═O) and asymmetric ν(C–O) peaks represents the existence of oxalates that bridge with metal atoms coordinated to four oxygen atoms. Additionally, the ν(O–H) stretching of the OH group and δ(O–H) peaks clearly indicate that the oxalate compound was converted to a hydroxide compound in an alkaline solution.
(31−33)
However, the peak at 1357 cm
–1
corresponding to asymmetric ν(C–O) remained slightly unchanged, indicating that not all the Ni–Fe oxalates were transformed to Ni–Fe hydroxide. These results were also consistent with the XPS spectra of the Ni–Fe oxalate before and after immersing the sample in the alkaline solution. The C
2
O
4
2–
peaks in C 1s and O 1s show that Ni–Fe hydroxide incorporated with oxalate was formed after the conversion process in alkaline solution (
Figure S4
). The oxalate anions incorporated in Ni–Fe hydroxide play a critical role in improving OER performance by acting as a strong oxidation sites of NiFe in oxalate due to the electron-withdrawing property. In addition, the oxalate anions work to stabilize the high valance state metal centers, which are the key active intermediates for OER.
(17)

x
-10. (d) Adsorption–desorption isotherm of the NiFeC
2
O
4

x

div.div:
Notably, when the Ni–Fe oxalate was converted to Ni–Fe hydroxide, the smooth surface of the Ni–Fe oxalate (
Figure S3b
) was transformed into rough and thick nanowires evenly covered with villi-shaped nanostructures, as shown in
Figure
3
c. The formation of villi-shaped nanostructures on the surface may be ascribed to the difference in molecular weight between the oxalate and hydroxide, along with the release of CO
2
gas during the conversion process (
eq 6
).
(6)

The porous villi-shaped architecture of the Ni–Fe hydroxide was further analyzed by N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherm plots. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of Ni–Fe hydroxide (197.0 m
2
g
–1
) is much larger than that of the Ni–Fe oxalate (11.8 m
2
g
–1
), leading to a greater number of catalytic sites for the OER (
Figure
3
d).

To evaluate the mutual effect between the proximate Ni and Fe atoms, which is essential for regulating the electronic structure of the active sites to enhance the OER kinetics, the OER activity of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 was measured using a standard three-electrode system in 1.0 M KOH.
(17)
For comparison, bare Ni foam and Ni(OH)
2
were used as the working electrodes.
Figure
4
a shows the LSV of the electrodes with the iR-compensation. NiFe(OH)
x
-10 has a more positive Ni
2+
/Ni
3+
oxidation peak than on the Ni(OH)
2
. It is because incorporated Fe
3+
can be attributed to the anodic shift of the Ni
2+
/Ni
3+
transition peak by stabilizing of the Ni
2+
oxidation state.
(34,35)
NiFe(OH)
x
-10 exhibited a remarkably low overpotential of 277 mV at 100 mA cm
–2
, which was considerably better than the other two electrodes (429 mV for Ni(OH)
2
and 499 mV for bare Ni foam). These results are in good agreement with the previous results stating that Ni and Fe catalysts located on opposite sides of the volcanic plot are attributed to achieve a balanced metal–OH bond strength,
(10,36)
which is one primary factor determining the OER activity. In detail, from in operando XAS and density functional theory calculation analysis, the high OER activity is attributable to the substitution of Fe
3+
cations for Ni
3+
cations into the lattice of Ni–Fe-based electrocatalysts. Although the bond length of Fe–O is similar to that of Ni–O, Fe
3+
sites Ni–Fe-based electrocatalysts show significantly superior OER activity than Ni
3+
sites in Ni based- or Ni–Fe-based electrocatalysts and Fe
3+
sites in Fe-based electrocatalysts.
(37)
The electrocatalytic kinetics of the electrodes toward the OER were investigated using the Tafel plots derived from the corresponding polarization curves in
Figure
4
b. The Tafel slope was fitted by the Tafel equation: η =
b
log
j
+
a
(where η represents the overpotential,
b
is the Tafel slope, and
j
represents the current density). The Tafel slope of the NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrode showed the lowest OER Tafel slope of 54 mV dec
–1
, exhibiting the most favorable OER kinetics compared to the other two electrodes (89 mV dec
–1
for Ni(OH)
2
and 98 mV dec
–1
for bare Ni foam). These results were attributed to the optimized regulation of the electronic structure of the active sites, arising from the atomic level mix of Ni and Fe in the electrode. To understand the ease of charge transfer, EIS was carried out in 1.0 M KOH, as shown in
Figure
4
c. The acquired Nyquist plots were fitted with NOVA software using the equivalent circuit model shown in inset of
Figure
4
c. The small semicircle of the Nyquist plot representing the charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
) suggests a rapid charge transfer at the interface.
(38,39)
The outstanding OER performance of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 stems from the fast charge transfer of 0.45 Ω, which could be observed in its smallest semicircular plot as compared to those of the other two electrodes (4.32 Ω for Ni(OH)
2
and 9.33 Ω for bare Ni foam).

div.p:
Figure 4. Comparison of the OER performance of the bare Ni foam, Ni(OH)
2
, and NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrodes: (a) LSV polarization curves, (b) Tafel plots, (c) Nyquist plots, and (d) double-layer capacitance estimation using voltammetry at various scan rates. The slopes represent the ECSA.

div.div:
Large electrochemical active surface areas (ECSAs) are critical in determining the electrochemical performance of electrodes and can provide more exposed active sites. The ECSA was estimated in a potential interval from 0.94 to 1.04 V
versus
RHE with different scan rates ranging from 0 to 100 mV s
–1
without faradaic currents (
Figure S6
). The formula used was ECSA =
C
dl
/
C
s
, where
C
dl
is the electrochemical double-layer capacitance and
C
s
is the specific capacitance of a flat surface of the electrode (0.04 mF cm
–2
).
(38−41)
As shown in
Figure
4
d, NiFe(OH)
x
-10 possessed the highest
C
dl
among the electrodes, which was almost 1.8- and 2.7-times larger than that of Ni(OH)
2
and bare Ni foam, respectively. The high
C
dl
implies that NiFe(OH)
x
-10 possesses a large number of active sites owing to the high porosity and large surface area of the hierarchical villi-shaped architecture, contributing to an enhanced OER. Therefore, from these results, we concluded that the superior OER activity of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 was a result of the synergetic effect of the atomic level bimetallic blending of Ni–Fe along with rapid charge transfer and large surface area arising from the hierarchically one-dimensional villi-shaped architecture.

In general, as the isolated monometal phases in some Ni–Fe-based electrodes do not work as active species for the OER,
(42−44)
the effect of the ratio of Ni and Fe on the electrochemical performance of Ni–Fe bimetallic-based catalysts was investigated in detail. The LSV polarization curves of NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
with different ratios of Ni and Fe are shown in
Figure
5
a. As shown in
Figure
5
b, the overpotential of the NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
electrodes decreased continuously until the concentration of Fe
3+
increased to 10 mM, and subsequently increased inversely when the Fe
3+
concentration increased to 30 mM; NiFe(OH)
x
-2.5 (310 mV), NiFe(OH)
x
-5 (298 mV), NiFe(OH)
x
-7.5 (287 mV), NiFe(OH)
x
-10 (277 mV), NiFe(OH)
x
-20 (291 mV), and NiFe(OH)
x
-30 (301 mV) at 100 mA cm
–2
. The NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrode with an Ni to Fe ratio of approximately 0.67:0.33 exhibited a superior OER property and had a similar tendency to that observed in previous studies for Ni–Fe-based catalysts with a ratio of 7:3.
(45−48)

div.p:
Figure 5. OER performance of the NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
(
Z
= 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 20, and 30 mM). (a) LSV polarization curves; (b) corresponding overpotentials at a current density of 100 mA cm
–2
and changes in the Fe content of obtained samples with different concentrations of FeCl
3
; (c) Tafel plots; (d) charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
) values corresponding to Nyquist plots (
Figure S7
); (e) double-layer capacitance estimation using voltammetry at various scan rates and corresponding linear slopes; and (f) ECSA-normalized LSV polarization curves.

div.div:
To explore the OER activity of the different electrocatalysts, the Tafel slopes of the NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
electrodes were derived from the corresponding polarization curves, as shown in
Figure
5
c. Although the NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrode exhibited the lowest OER Tafel slope of 54 mV, all NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
electrodes showed similar Tafel slope values, implying that the entire Ni–Fe hydroxide-based catalyst electrodes possessed the same rate-determining step for the OER. Furthermore, EIS on the NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
electrode was carried out to clearly verify the effect of electron transfer capability on the OER performance as a function of the ratio of Ni to Fe. As shown in
Figures
5
d and
S6
,
R
ct
clearly decreased with increasing Fe
3+
concentrations from 2.5 to 10 mM. It subsequently increased inversely from 10 to 30 mM, suggesting that the electrode possessed faster electron transfer kinetics at the interface between the electrodes and electrolyte due to the optimized blending of Ni and Fe at the atomic level; NiFe(OH)
x
-2.5 (0.70 Ω), NiFe(OH)
x
-5 (0.64 Ω), NiFe(OH)
x
-7.5 (0.54 Ω), NiFe(OH)
x
-10 (0.45 Ω), NiFe(OH)
x
-20 (0.55 Ω), and NiFe(OH)
x
-30 (0.58 Ω).

The results of ECSA estimated based on
C
dl
are shown in
Figure
5
e. Notably, although NiFe(OH)
x
-2.5 showed a capacitance value similar to that of Ni(OH)
2
(
Figure
4
d; implying a comparable number of active sites for the OER), it exhibited a lower overpotential, charge transfer resistance, and OER Tafel slope compared to those of Ni(OH)
2
. These results indicate that bimetallic catalysts are more advantageous for the OER than monometallic catalysts. Furthermore, in the OER polarization curves normalized by the ECSA, as shown in
Figure
5
f, NiFe(OH)
x
-10 displayed the highest current density among the NiFe(OH)
x
-
Z
electrodes, demonstrating that it was the most active electrode due to its excellent intrinsic activity with the optimized bimetal content, large surface area of the nanostructure, and improved conductivity.
Table S1
presents recent studies on Ni–Fe-based electrodes for the OER, indicating that the OER activity and stability of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 are superior to those of other electrodes.

Long-term stability is vital in determining the wide usage of the suggested electrocatalysts in the industry. The cycling stability of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 was investigated through a chronopotentiometry approach with an iR-compensation at 100 mA cm
–2
for 100 h. As shown in
Figure
6
a, NiFe(OH)
x
-10 exhibited an outstanding stable OER behavior with a constant overpotential, showing only a 3.6% potential rise after 100 h (from 280 to 290 mV). The SEM images of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 after the stability test revealed that the original morphology of the electrode remained unchanged, confirming the excellent stability of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 for the OER (
Figure
6
b–d).

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) Chronopotentiometry of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 at a current density of 100 mA cm
–2
for 100 h. SEM images of the NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrode after the stability test for (b) pristine electrode and (c) that after 1 h (d) and 100 h, both of which exhibit negligible alternation in morphology.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, Ni–Fe oxalate nanostructures were successfully synthesized through a simple
in situ
precipitation-induced growth method on Ni foam in a short time without external energy consumption. As the Fe
3+
concentration increased from 2.5 to 3 mM, the morphology of the Ni oxalate nanosheet was transformed to pointed nanowires with an average diameter of 100 nm, which was accompanied by an increase in the ratio of Fe to Ni. Furthermore, villi-shaped Ni–Fe hydroxide nanowires were obtained by immersing the Ni–Fe oxalate in 1 M KOH solution for 5 min. The mechanism was attributed to a self-template conversion from oxalate to hydroxide with the release of CO
2
, providing larger catalytic active sites for water oxidation. At an optimized ratio of Ni and Fe, the NiFe(OH)
x
-10 electrode exhibited an outstanding performance against the OER with a low overpotential of 277 mV at 100 mA cm
–2
. This was a significant improvement over monometallic Ni(OH)
2
and pristine Ni foam. The enhanced electrochemical properties were ascribed to the synergetic effects of the optimized mixing of Ni and Fe at the atomic level, the increased surface area leading to high active sites, and reduced charge transfer resistivity. The cycling stability of NiFe(OH)
x
-10 for the OER performance revealed a stable overpotential without significant morphological changes at 100 mA cm
–2
for 100 h. This work demonstrates an inexpensive Ni–Fe based electrocatalyst with an outstanding intrinsic catalyst activity. Given the high OER activity, stability, easy synthesis, and large-scale applicability, the findings are important for the design and synthesis of Ni–Fe hydroxide derived from Ni–Fe oxalates.

A review on development of industrial processes and emerging techniques for production of hydrogen from renewable and sustainable sources
Chaubey, Rashmi; Sahu, Satanand; James, Olusola O.; Maity, Sudip

A review. Hydrogen is considered as the fuel for next generation and extensive research is being pursued for search of new techniques for hydrogen prodn. from renewable sources. There is a diverse collection of hydrogen prodn. processes at their different stages of development. This review paper analyzes the industrial and emerging hydrogen prodn. technologies. These processes include steam methane reformation, partial oxidn., autothermal reforming, steam iron, plasma reforming, thermochem. water splitting and biol. processes. Till date, steam reformation of methane is the most used industrial technique and its efficiency can go up to 85%. It meets up to 50% of total hydrogen consumption in the world. Continuous research is going on to enhance prodn. yield as well as to improve the process economics. Considerable work is going on about sorption enhanced reforming and membrane reactor for this purpose. Partial oxidn. and autothermal reforming processes are the other two processes which are also used for industrial. The most sought process is the thermochem. water splitting using sunlight. Several research institutes are engaged in the development of hydrogen prodn. technologies using renewable sources. Plasma reformation and biol. processes are intensively worked out throughout the globe. The present article reviews the recent developments in industrial techniques which will lead to enhancement of hydrogen prodn. The non-conventional techniques are described in this article as emerging techniques, which are the promising approaches for hydrogen prodn. from biomass, an abundant, clean and renewable source.

Coupling NiSe2-Ni2P heterostructure nanowrinkles for highly efficient overall water splitting
Wang, Pengyan; Pu, Zonghua; Li, Wenqiang; Zhu, Jiawei; Zhang, Chengtian; Zhao, Yufeng; Mu, Shichun
Journal of Catalysis

Developing catalysts with high efficiency and low-cost toward overall water splitting is crit. for the sustainable energy conversion. Herein, a facile wet-chem. route followed by successive selenization and partial phosphorization treatments is presented to synthesize the heterostructure combining NiSe2 and Ni2P coupled nanowrinkles on Ni foam (NiSe2-Ni2P/NF). DFT calcn. results confirm that the NiSe2 coupled with Ni2P in NiSe2-Ni2P/NF can promote the water adsorption process, speeding up the whole catalytic kinetics for overall water splitting. Benefitting from the synergistic effects between NiSe2 and Ni2P, the optimal NiSe2-Ni2P/NF electrode exhibits excellent catalytic performances toward both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in alk. media. Impressively, for OER such heterogeneous nanowrinkles merely require an ultralow overpotential of 220 mV to reach the c.d. of 50 mA cm-2. Moreover, when utilized as a bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting, the c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 can be delivered at an ultralow cell voltage of 1.50 V, which is among the lowest values of current non-precious metal catalysts. This work provides a unique strategy for exploring highly efficient heterostructure catalysts toward water splitting and beyond.

Single layer graphene encapsulating non-precious metals as high-performance electrocatalysts for water oxidation
Cui, Xiaoju; Ren, Pengju; Deng, Dehui; Deng, Jiao; Bao, Xinhe

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is recognized as a key half-reaction in water electrolysis for clean hydrogen energy, which is kinetically not favored and usually requires precious metal catalysts such as IrO2 and RuO2 to reduce the overpotential. The major challenge in using non-precious metals in place of these precious metal catalysts for OER is their low efficiency and poor stability, which urgently demand new concepts and strategies to tackle this issue. Herein, we report a universal strategy to directly synthesize single layer graphene encapsulating uniform earth-abundant 3d transition-metal nanoparticles such as Fe, Co, Ni and their alloys in a confined channel of mesoporous silica. The single at. thickness of the graphene shell immensely promotes the electron transfer from the encapsulated metals to the graphene surface, which efficiently optimizes the electronic structure of the graphene surface and thereby triggers the OER activity of the inert graphene surface. We investigated a series of non-precious 3d metals encapsulated within single layer graphene, and found that the encapsulated FeNi alloy showed the best OER activity in alk. solns. with only 280 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm-2, and also possessed a high durability after 10 000 cycles. Both the activity and durability of the non-precious catalyst even exceed that of the com. IrO2 catalyst, showing great potential to replace precious metal catalysts in the OER.

Self-Supported Porous NiSe2 Nanowrinkles as Efficient Bifunctional Electrocatalysts for Overall Water Splitting
Zhang, Jie; Wang, Ying; Zhang, Chi; Gao, Hui; Lv, Lanfen; Han, Lulu; Zhang, Zhonghua

Developing low cost, highly active, and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting is significant for sustainable energy systems. Herein, we report the synthesis of three-dimensional porous nickel diselenide nanowrinkles anchored on nickel foam through fabricating nickel oxalate nanosheets on nickel foam by immersion, followed by selenization under a selenium vapor atm. The hybrid material exhibits superior hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen evolution reaction performances with high activity (low overpotential), favorable kinetics, and outstanding durability in alk. solns. An overpotential of merely 166 mV is needed to reach 10 mA cm-2 for hydrogen evolution reaction and 235 mV for oxygen evolution reaction. The NiOOH species formed at the NiSe2 surface serves as the catalytic sites. Moreover, the electrolyzer only needs a cell voltage of 1.64 V to deliver 10 mA cm-2 for overall water splitting and shows excellent long-term stability (80 h at 10 mA cm-2). The unique porous nanowrinkle structure, improved elec. cond., fast charge transfer kinetics, and large electrochem. surface area are responsible for the highly active and stable electrocatalytic performance toward hydrogen evolution reaction/oxygen evolution reaction.

Efficient electrocatalysis of overall water splitting by ultrasmall NixCo3-xS4 coupled Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays
Wu, Yuanyuan; Liu, Yipu; Li, Guo-Dong; Zou, Xu; Lian, Xinran; Wang, Dejun; Sun, Lei; Asefa, Tewodros; Zou, Xiaoxin
Nano Energy

The overall water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen is one of the most promising ways to store intermittent solar and wind energy in the form of chem. fuels. However, this process is quite thermodynamically uphill, and thus needs to be mediated simultaneously by efficient hydrogen evolving and oxygen evolving catalysts to get any feasible output from it. Herein, we report the synthesis of such a catalyst comprising ultrasmall NixCo3-xS4-decorated Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays supported on nickel foam (NF) via a partial cation exchange reaction between NF-supported Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays and cobalt(II) ions. We show that the as-prepd. material, denoted as NixCo3-xS4/Ni3S2/NF, can serve as a self-standing, noble metal-free, highly active and stable, bifunctional electrocatalyst for the two half reactions involved in the overall water splitting: the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Furthermore, we demonstrate that a high-performance electrolyzer for the overall water splitting reaction can be assembled by using NixCo3-xS4/Ni3S2/NF as the electrocatalyst at both the cathode and the anode sides of the electrolyzer. This electrolyzer delivers water-splitting current densities of 10 and 100 mA/cm2 at applied potentials of 1.53 and 1.80 V, resp., with remarkable stability for >200 h in both cases. The electrolyzer's performance is much better than the performances of electrolyzers assembled from many types of other bifunctional electrocatalysts as catalyst couple. Moreover, the overall performance of the electrolyzer is comparable with the performances of electrolyzers contg. two different, benchmark, monofunctional HER and OER electrocatalyst couple (i.e., Pt/C-IrO2).

Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction for energy conversion and storage: A comprehensive review
Tahir, Muhammad; Pan, Lun; Idrees, Faryal; Zhang, Xiangwen; Wang, Li; Zou, Ji-Jun; Wang, Zhong Lin

Water oxidn. or oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysis got much attention in the last few years because of its prime role in water splitting, rechargeable metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Therefore, the development of efficient, abundant and economical catalysts for water oxidn. reaction is one of the main subjects of present study in renewable energies. This review article summarizes the very recent efforts in the field of OER electrocatalysis along with the faced challenges. The solns. to these challenges also outline with appropriate examples of scientific literatures. Significantly, the present review will provide the stds. to evaluate the activity and stability for heterogeneous OER catalysts. It will clearly summarize the future directions and applications, esp. the combination of sustainable energy utilization (like triboelec. nanogenerator) with water splitting. The providing study will help to explore and develop better catalysts and units for practical applications and will offer basic understanding of OER process along with the std. parameters to evaluate the performance.

Electrocatalysis for the oxygen evolution reaction: recent development and future perspectives
Suen, Nian-Tzu; Hung, Sung-Fu; Quan, Quan; Zhang, Nan; Xu, Yi-Jun; Chen, Hao Ming

(

There is still an ongoing effort to search for sustainable, clean and highly efficient energy generation to satisfy the energy needs of modern society. Among various advanced technologies, electrocatalysis for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a key role and numerous new electrocatalysts have been developed to improve the efficiency of gas evolution. Along the way, enormous effort has been devoted to finding high-performance electrocatalysts, which has also stimulated the invention of new techniques to investigate the properties of materials or the fundamental mechanism of the OER. This accumulated knowledge not only establishes the foundation of the mechanism of the OER, but also points out the important criteria for a good electrocatalyst based on a variety of studies. Even though it may be difficult to include all cases, the aim of this review is to inspect the current progress and offer a comprehensive insight toward the OER. This review begins with examg. the theor. principles of electrode kinetics and some measurement criteria for achieving a fair evaluation among the catalysts. The second part of this review acquaints some materials for performing OER activity, in which the metal oxide materials build the basis of OER mechanism while non-oxide materials exhibit greatly promising performance toward overall water-splitting. Attention of this review is also paid to in situ approaches to electrocatalytic behavior during OER, and this information is crucial and can provide efficient strategies to design perfect electrocatalysts for OER. Finally, the OER mechanism from the perspective of both recent exptl. and theor. investigations is discussed, as well as probable strategies for improving OER performance with regards to future developments.

Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) involves multiple electron-transfer processes, resulting in a high activation barrier. Developing catalysts with low overpotential and high intrinsic activity toward OER is crit. but challenging. Here we report a major advancement in decreasing the overpotential for oxygen evolution reaction. Ni foam-supported Fe-doped β-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets achieve an overpotential of 219 mV at the geometric c.d. of 10 mA cm-2. To our knowledge, this is the best value reported for Ni- or Fe hydroxide-based OER catalysts. In addn., the catalyst yields a c.d. of 6.25 mA cm-2 at the overpotential of 300 mV when it is normalized to the electrochem. surface area of the catalyst. This intrinsic catalytic activity is also better than the values reported for most state-of-the-art OER catalysts at the same overpotential.

Understanding the pathways of catalyst degrdn. during the O evolution reaction is a cornerstone in the development of efficient and stable electrolyzers, since even for the most promising Ir based anodes the harsh reaction conditions are detrimental. The dissoln. mechanism is complex and the correlation to the O evolution reaction itself is still poorly understood. Here, by coupling a scanning flow cell with inductively coupled plasma and online electrochem. mass spectrometers, the authors monitor the O evolution and degrdn. products of Ir and Ir oxides in situ. At high anodic potentials several dissoln. routes become possible, including formation of gaseous IrO3. From exptl. data, possible pathways are proposed for the O-evolution-triggered dissoln. of Ir and the role of common intermediates for these reactions is discussed.

Exploring highly efficient electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and unveiling their activity origin are pivotal for energy conversion technologies. Herein, atomically distributed Ni sites over a N-doped hollow carbon matrix are reported as a promising electrocatalyst for OER in alk. conditions. Significantly boosted activity is obsd. after the decoration of the active Ni sites with well-controlled coordination geometry. Results of X-ray absorption spectroscopy investigation and d. functional theory (DFT) calcn. reveal that the effective electronic coupling via the Ni-N coordination can move down the Fermi level and lower the adsorption energy of intermediates, thus resulting in the facilitated OER kinetics.

Smith, Paul F.; Deibert, Benjamin J.; Kaushik, Shivam; Gardner, Graeme; Hwang, Shinjae; Wang, Hao; Al-Sharab, Jafar F.; Garfunkel, Eric; Fabris, Laura; Li, Jing; Dismukes, G. Charles

Surface-directed corner-sharing MnO6 octahedra within numerous manganese oxide compds. contg. Mn3+ or Mn4+ oxidn. states show strikingly different catalytic activities for water oxidn., paradoxically poorest for Mn4+ oxides, regardless of oxidn. assay (photochem. and electrochem.). This is demonstrated herein by comparing cryst. oxides consisting of Mn3+ (manganite, γ-MnOOH; bixbyite, Mn2O3), Mn4+ (pyrolusite, β-MnO2) and multiple monophasic mixed-valence manganese oxides. Like all Mn4+ oxides, pure β-MnO2 has no detectable catalytic activity, while γ-MnOOH (tetragonally distorted Mn3+O6, D4h symmetry) is significantly more active and Mn2O3 (trigonal antiprismatic Mn3+O6, D3d symmetry) is the most active. γ-MnOOH deactivates during catalytic turnover simultaneous with the disappearance of crystallog. defined corner-sharing Mn3+O6 and the appearance of Mn4+. In a comparison of 2D-layered cryst. birnessites (δ-MnO2), the monovalent Mn4+ form is catalytically inert, while the hexagonal polymorph, contg. few out-of-layer corner-sharing Mn3+O6, has ∼10-fold higher catalytic activity than the triclinic polymorph, contg. in-plane edge-sharing Mn3+O6. These electronic and structural correlations point toward the more flexible (corner-shared) Mn3+O6 sites, over more rigid (edge-shared) sites as substantially more active catalytic centers. Electrochem. measurements show and ligand field theory predicts that, among corner-shared Mn3+O6 sites, those possessing D3d ligand field symmetry have stronger covalent Mn-O bonding to the six equiv. oxygen ligands, which we ascribe as responsible for more efficient and faster electrolytic water oxidn. In contrast, D4h Mn3+O6 sites have weaker Mn-O bonding to the two axial oxygen ligands, have sepd. electrochem. oxidn. waves for Mn and O, and are catalytically less efficient and exhibit slower catalytic turnover. By controlling the ligand field geometry and strength to oxygen ligands, we have identified the key variables for tuning water oxidn. activity by manganese oxides. We apply these findings to propose a mechanism for water oxidn. by the CaMn4O5 catalytic site of natural photosynthesis.

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a vital half-reaction in water splitting and metal-air batteries. Developing earth-abundant, highly efficient and durable OER catalysts has faced huge challenges until now, because OER is a strict kinetic sluggish process. Herein, we report the construction of hierarchically porous graphitized carbon (HPGC) supported NiFe layered double hydroxides (LDHs) with a core-shell structure (denoted as
[email protected]
) by a facile strategy. The HPGC was first obtained by pyrolyzing phenolic resin nanospheres with FeCl3 and ZnCl2 as the catalyst and the activator, resp. Then the NiFe LDH arrays were directly grown on the HPGC by a one-step hydrothermal method. The as-synthesized
[email protected]
reveals excellent OER properties with a low onset potential, a lower overpotential of 265 mV (corresponding to the c.d. at 10 mA cm-2) and a small Tafel slope (56 mV per decade). And its catalytic activity is even superior to that of the start-of-the-art noble-metal catalyst IrO2/C. Notably, the
[email protected]
electrode shows admirable stability measured by performing 2000 cycle CVs and long-term electrolysis for 50 h. The prominent performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect between the NiFe-LDHs and the hierarchically porous graphitized carbon, in which the former can increase the exposure of the active sites, while the latter can increase the charge transfer efficiency. Our research implies the possibility for the development of low-cost layered double hydroxides as a promising candidate in electrochem. energy storage and conversion equipment.

Design and synthesis of materials for efficient electrochem. transformation of H2O to H2 and of hydroxyl ions to O in alk. environments is of paramount importance in reducing energy losses in H2O-alkali electrolyzers. Here, using 3d-M hydr(oxy)oxides, with distinct stoichiometries and morphologies in the H evolution reaction (HER) and the O evolution reaction (OER) regions, the authors establish the overall catalytic activities for these reaction as a function of a more fundamental property, a descriptor, OH-M2+δ bond strength (0 ≤ δ ≤ 1.5). This relation exhibits trends in reactivity (Mn < Fe < Co < Ni), which is governed by the strength of the OH-M2+δ energetic (Ni < Co < Fe < Mn). These trends are independent of the source of the OH, either the supporting electrolyte (for the OER) or the H2O dissocn. product (for the HER). The successful identification of these electrocatalytic trends provides the foundation for rational design of active sites' for practical alk. HER and OER electrocatalysts.

NiFe-based materials have shown impressive electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The mutual effect between proximate Ni and Fe atoms is essential in regulating the electronic structure of the active site to boost the OER kinetics. Detailed studies confirm that the sepd. monometal phases in NiFe-based materials are detrimental to OER. Thus, the high-level blending of Ni and Fe in NiFe-based OER electrocatalysts is crit. Herein, an NiFe oxalate nanomesh array based on solid solns. between nickel (II) oxalate and iron (II) oxalate is prepd. through a facile surfactant-free approach in the presence of the reductive oxalate anions. The integrated electrode can efficiently catalyze water oxidn. to reach a c.d. of 50 mA cm-2 with a small overpotential of 203 mV in a 1.0 M KOH aq. soln. The high efficiency can be attributed to the at. level mix of Ni and Fe in the solid solns. and the hierarchical porous structure of the nanomesh array. These two aspects bring about fast kinetics, efficient mass diffusion, and quick charge transfer, which are the three major pos. factors for a high-performance heterogeneous electrocatalyst.

Fe plays a crit., but not yet understood, role in enhancing the activity of the Ni-based O evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts. The authors report electrochem., in situ elec., photoelectron spectroscopy, and x-ray diffraction measurements on Ni1-xFex(OH)2/Ni1-xFexOOH thin films to study the changes in electronic properties, OER activity, and structure as a result of Fe inclusion. The authors developed a simple method for purifn. of KOH electrolyte that uses pptd. bulk Ni(OH)2 to absorb Fe impurities. Cyclic voltammetry on rigorously Fe-free Ni(OH)2/NiOOH reveals new Ni redox features and no significant OER current until >400 mV overpotential, different from previous reports which were likely affected by Fe impurities. The authors show through controlled crystn. that β-NiOOH is less active for OER than the disordered γ-NiOOH starting material and that previous reports of increased activity for β-NiOOH are due to incorporation of Fe-impurities during the crystn. process. Through-film in situ cond. measurements show a >30-fold increase in film cond. with Fe addn., but this change in cond. is not sufficient to explain the obsd. changes in activity. Measurements of activity as a function of film thickness on Au and glassy C substrates are consistent with the hypothesis that Fe exerts a partial-charge-transfer activation effect on Ni, similar to that obsd. for noble-metal electrode surfaces. These results have significant implications for the design and study of Ni1-xFexOOH OER electrocatalysts, which are the fastest measured OER catalysts under basic conditions.

To achieve the global goals related to renewable energy and responsible prodn., technologies that ensure the circular economy of metals and chems. in recycling processes are a necessity. The recycling of spent Nd-Fe-B magnets typically results in rare-earth element (REE)-free wastewater that has a high ferric ion concn. as well as oxalate groups and for which there are only a few economically viable methods for disposal or reuse. The current research provides a new approach for the effective recovery of oxalic acid, and the results suggest that during the initial oxalate group sepn. stage, >99% of oxalate ions can be pptd. as ferrous oxalate (FeC2O4·2H2O) by an ultrasound-assisted iron powder replacement method (Fe/Fe(III) = 2, tu/s = 5 min, T = 50°). Subsequently, almost all FeC2O4·2H2O was dissolved using 6 mol/L HCl (T = 65°, t = 5 min) and the dissolved oxalates were found to mainly exist in the form of H2C2O4. Furthermore, over 80% of the oxalic acid was recovered via crystn. by cooling the oxalate contg. HCl soln. to 5°. After oxalic acid crystn., the residual raffinate acid soln. can then be recirculated back to the ferrous oxalate leaching stage, to decrease any oxalic acid losses. This treatment protocol for high-iron REE-free soln. not only avoids the potential harm to the environment due to the wastewater but also significantly improves the circular economy of chems. in the typical utilization in permanent magnet recycling processes. An effective approach involving the ultrasound-assisted redn. pptn., HCl digestion, and cooling crystn. is described to recover oxalic acid from the waste soln. produced during the recycling of spent Nd-Fe-B magnets.

The extn. of zinc and iron was performed using Cyanex 923. Cyanex 923 selectively extd. Zn(II) and Fe(III) from the acidic chloride soln. leaving behind Fe(II) in the raffinate. The loaded org. was stripped efficiently using oxalic acid to ppt. Water splitting is widely considered to be a promising strategy for clean and efficient energy prodn. For the 1st time the authors report an in situ growth of iron-nickel nitride nanostructures on surface-redox-etching Ni foam (FeNi3N/NF) as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. This method does not require a specially added nickel precursor nor an oxidizing agent, but achieves well-dispersed iron-nickel nitride nanostructures that are grown directly on the nickel foam surface. The com. Ni foam in this work not only acts as a substrate but also serves as a slow-releasing nickel precursor that is induced by redox-etching of Fe3+. FeCl2 is a more preferable iron precursor than FeCl3 for no matter quality of FeNi3N growth or its electrocatalytic behaviors. The obtained FeNi3N/NF exhibits extraordinarily high activities for both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) with low overpotentials of 202 and 75 mV at 10 mA/cm2, Tafel slopes of 40 and 98 mV/dec, resp. The presented FeNi3N/NF catalyst has an extremely good durability, reflecting in >400 h of consistent galvanostatic electrolysis without any visible voltage elevation.

The morphol. evolution of the Ni-Co binary hydroxides was studied varying from nanosheets, to nanoplate-nanospheres, to nanorods and to a nanoparticle geometry by simply controlling the Co:Ni ratio in the initial reactant. High capacitances of 1030 F g-1 and 804 F g-1 can be achieved in the 1-dimensional nanorod morphol. at mass loading of 1 mg cm-2 and 2.8 mg cm-2 at a c.d. of 3 A g-1, resp. The asym. supercapacitor delivers a high energy d. of 26.3 Wh kg-1 at the power d. of 320 W kg-1. Efficient and durable electrocatalysts for water splitting (both the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER)) are required for the replacement of expensive noble metal-based catalysts used in water electrolysis devices. Herein, we describe the inexpensive synthesis of electrochem. deposited nickel iron sulfides on nickel foam (NiFeS/NF) and their use as highly efficient bi-functional water splitting catalysts that can meet the current energy demands. The NiFeS/NF electrocatalysts exhibited low overpotentials of approx. 231 mV for the OER and 180 mV for the HER in 1 M KOH. Moreover, the NiFeS/NF electrocatalysts exhibited a turnover frequency of one order of magnitude higher than those of state-of-the-art noble metal catalysts (RuO2 and Pt/C) for the OER and HER. In addn. to this excellent activity, the bi-functional catalyst also exhibited an outstanding OER and HER electrode stability for over 200 h with minimal loss in activity. Further, it can be directly used in the practical application of alk. electrolyte membrane water electrolysis. The high performance, prolonged electrode stability, and facile synthesis as an adherent coating on nickel foam suggest that NiFeS/NF electrocatalysts might be suitable for use as alternative com. viable catalysts.

A convenient template- and surfactant-free strategy has been developed to prep. porous hierarchical Ni nanostructures by directly calcining the nickel-based flower-like precursor in Ar. The precursor is preformed by refluxing the soln. of nickel nitrate and the co-precipitators of hexamethylenetetramine and oxalic acid at 100 °C for 6 h. Ni-Fe and Ni-Fe-Co mixed-metal oxide (MMO) films were studied as electrocatalysts for the O evolution reaction (OER) in 0.1 M KOH. In an effort to optimize MMO morphol., aniline was used as a capping agent to produce high-surface-area Ni-Fe-Co films on Raney Ni supports. This catalyst exhibits enhanced mass activity in comparison to the Ni-Fe OER electrocatalysts reported to date. Cyclic voltammetry shows changes in the potential of the Ni2+/3+ transitions in Fe- or Co-contg. MMO films. In situ x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) anal. confirms that Fe acts to stabilize Ni in the 2+ oxidn. state, while Co facilitates oxidn. to the 3+ state. The results of this study support the recent claims that Fe (not Ni) is the OER active site. The OER enhancement of the ternary Ni-Fe-Co catalyst results from two effects: (1) the charge-transfer effects of Co gave the conductive NiIIIOOH phase at lower overpotential, thus activating the Fe sites which are otherwise inaccessible to electron transfer in the nonconductive NiII(OH)2 host lattice, and (2) XAS anal. shows that the presence of Co effectively shrinks the Ni and Fe local geometry, likely resulting in an optimized Fe-OH/OOH bond strength. Anal. of heat-treatment effects indicates that calcination at 400° improves the OER activity of Ni-Fe-Co but deactivates Ni-Fe. Annealing studies under Ar show that MMO surfaces with a hydrated Ni(OH)2 phase and a cryst. NiO phase exhibit nearly identical OER activities. Finally, the morphol. of the MMO catalyst film on Raney Ni support provides excellent catalyst dispersion and should result in high active-site use for use in technol. relevant gas-diffusion electrodes.

A review. Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalyzed by non-precious metals and their compds. in alk. medium is an attractive area of energy research for the generation of hydrogen from water. The 3d transition metals, particularly, Ni and Co show better OER activity than others in alk. medium. Ni and Co based oxygen-evolving catalysts (OECs) experience an enormous enhancement in the OER activity either by incidental or intentional Fe doping/incorporation. To account for this, different roles of Fe that it exerts when incorporated into these OECs are reported to be responsible. Unfortunately, the conclusions drawn in many related studies are often contradictory to one another. Important contradictory conclusions are: 1. a few studies claim Fe is the active site and Ni/Co are inactive while other studies claim Ni/Co and Fe act together in OER, 2. a few studies claim Fe3+ stays unoxidized while a few shows evidence for the existence of Fe4+, and 3. a few studies suggest Fe3+ is the faster site in Ni/Co OEC matrixes for OER but fail to explain similar effects obsd. with other OER matrixes. Many crit. exptl. and theor. investigations have been made recently to reveal this magical Fe effect and the results of those studies are coherently presented here with crit. discussion. This review is presented as it is inevitable to know the crit. roles of Fe effect in Ni/Co based OECs to succeed in energy efficient hydrogen generation in alk. medium.

The electrolysis of water to produce hydrogen and oxygen is a simple and attractive approach to store renewable energies in the form of chem. fuels. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a complex four-electron process that constitutes the most energy-inefficient step in water electrolysis. Here we describe a novel electrochem. method for the deposition of a family of thin-film transition metal (oxy)hydroxides as OER catalysts. The thin films have nanodomains of crystallinity with lattice spacing similar to those of double-layered hydroxides. The loadings of these thin-film catalysts were accurately detd. with a resoln. of below 1 μg cm-2 using an electrochem. quartz microcrystal balance. The loading-activity relations for various catalysts were established using voltammetry and impedance spectroscopy. The thin-film catalysts have up to four types of loading-activity dependence due to film nucleation and growth as well as the resistance of the films. A zone of intrinsic activity has been identified for all of the catalysts where the mass-averaged activity remains const. while the loading is increased. According to their intrinsic activities, the metal oxides can be classified into three categories: NiOx, MnOx, and FeOx belong to category I, which is the least active; CoOx and CoNiOx belong to category II, which has medium activity; and FeNiOx, CoFeOx, and CoFeNiOx belong to category III, which is the most active. The high turnover frequencies of CoFeOx and CoFeNiOx at low overpotentials and the simple deposition method allow the fabrication of high-performance anode electrodes coated with these catalysts. In 1 M KOH and with the most active electrode, overpotentials as low as 240 and 270 mV are required to reach 10 and 100 mA cm-2, resp.

Liu, Lisha; Rojac, Tadej; Damjanovic, Dragan; Di Michiel, Marco; Daniels, John

Dynamics of domain walls are among the main features that control strain mechanisms in ferroic materials. Here, we demonstrate that the domain-wall-controlled piezoelec. behavior in multiferroic BiFeO3 is distinct from that reported in classical ferroelecs. In situ X-ray diffraction was used to sep. the elec.-field-induced lattice strain and strain due to displacements of non-180° domain walls in polycryst. BiFeO3 over a wide frequency range. These piezoelec. strain mechanisms have opposing trends as a function of frequency. The lattice strain increases with increasing frequency, showing neg. piezoelec. phase angle (i.e., strain leads the elec. field), an unusual feature so far demonstrated only in the total macroscopic piezoelec. response. Domain-wall motion exhibits the opposite behavior, it decreases in magnitude with increasing frequency, showing more common pos. piezoelec. phase angle (i.e., strain lags behind the elec. field). Charge redistribution at conducting domain walls, oriented differently in different grain families, is demonstrated to be the cause.

The development of stable and efficient oxygen evolutional electrocatalysts is fundamental to the prodn. of hydrogen by water electrolysis. However, so far the majority of electrocatalysts require a substantial overpotential (η) (approx. >250 mV) to catalyze the bottleneck oxygen evolution reaction (OER). To overcome this large overpotential for OER, herein we report the growth of nickel-cobalt-selenide (NiCoSe2) nanosheets over 3D nickel foam (NF) via a facile and scalable electrodeposition method. The resulting 3D NiCoSe2/NF hybrid electrode requires an overpotential of merely 183 mV to reach the c.d. (J) of 10 mA cm-2. To the best of our knowledge, this is the lowest η value reported so far for any earth-abundant material-based OER electrocatalyst to attain the same c.d. Moreover, a significant redn. in Tafel slope (88 mV dec-1) is obsd. between bare NF and NiCoSe2/NF. Hence, as a result, the 3D hybrid NiCoSe2/NF OER electrode outperforms the previously reported electrocatalysts including the expensive state-of-the-art OER electrocatalysts like RuO2 and IrO2. Such enhancement in the OER catalytic efficiency of NiCoSe2 nanosheets over NF can be attributed to its enormous electrochem. active surface area (ECSA) (108 cm2), large roughness factor (270), highly conductive NF substrate, and the presence of multiple catalytically active OER species (NiOOH and CoOOH) on its surface. In addn., 3D hybrid NiCoSe2/NF electrocatalyst was tested for hydrazine oxidn. for its bifunctional utilization. Much lower onset potential values (-0.7 V vs. SCE) and high current densities (>200 mA cm-2) are obsd. for 3D hybrid NiCoSe2/NF when benchmarked against bare NF (-0.4 V and <50 mA cm-2). Furthermore, 3D hybrid NiCoSe2/NF OER electrode shows excellent stability of 50 h for continuous OER in strongly alk. solns. while maintaining its enormous ECSA, chem. compn., and structural morphol. The excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability, and facile prepn. method enable NiCoSe2/NF hybrid electrode to be a viable candidate for its widespread use in various water-splitting technologies.

Producing green hydrogen fuel from water is one of the most promising strategies for sustainable and clean energy supply in the future. Seeking for highly efficient, noble-metal-free and stable catalysts for typical electrochem. catalytic (EC), photoelectrochem. (PEC) and photocatalytic (PC) hydrogen prodn. has attracted much attention. In this work, for the first time, we rationally designed and fabricated an innovative class of

core-shell nanorod arrays (CSNS) on Ni foam. Thanks to the synergistic effect and catalytic role transformation between CdS nanorods and Ni3S2 nanosheets, CSNS was detd. to be a new type of multifunctional noble-metal-free catalyst, which exhibited highly stable and efficient H2 prodn. properties in EC, PEC and PC hydrogen prodn. systems. Specifically, with an optimal Ni3S2 shell thickness, CSNS achieved its highest PEC activity with an applied bias photon-to-current conversion efficiency (ABPE) of 7.9% and an extremely high H2 prodn. rate of 112.5 μmol cm-2 min-1. Moreover, a series of inconsistent catalytic behaviors were found during the EC, PEC and PC hydrogen prodn. procedures. By establishing three corresponding charge sepn. and transfer models, the underlying catalytic mechanisms and the dominant role transformations between CdS and Ni3S2 in these three catalytic systems were systematically investigated. This study provides a new strategy and guidelines for searching for suitable photocatalysts/electrocatalysts and core-shell multifunctional catalysts which can be used in an optional H2 prodn. system.

Fe plays a crit., but not yet understood, role in enhancing the activity of the Ni-based O evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts. The authors report electrochem., in situ elec., photoelectron spectroscopy, and x-ray diffraction measurements on Ni1-xFex(OH)2/Ni1-xFexOOH thin films to study the changes in electronic properties, OER activity, and structure as a result of Fe inclusion. The authors developed a simple method for purifn. of KOH electrolyte that uses pptd. bulk Ni(OH)2 to absorb Fe impurities. Cyclic voltammetry on rigorously Fe-free Ni(OH)2/NiOOH reveals new Ni redox features and no significant OER current until >400 mV overpotential, different from previous reports which were likely affected by Fe impurities. The authors show through controlled crystn. that β-NiOOH is less active for OER than the disordered γ-NiOOH starting material and that previous reports of increased activity for β-NiOOH are due to incorporation of Fe-impurities during the crystn. process. Through-film in situ cond. measurements show a >30-fold increase in film cond. with Fe addn., but this change in cond. is not sufficient to explain the obsd. changes in activity. Measurements of activity as a function of film thickness on Au and glassy C substrates are consistent with the hypothesis that Fe exerts a partial-charge-transfer activation effect on Ni, similar to that obsd. for noble-metal electrode surfaces. These results have significant implications for the design and study of Ni1-xFexOOH OER electrocatalysts, which are the fastest measured OER catalysts under basic conditions.

Gorlin Mikaela; Ferreira de Araujo Jorge; Reier Tobias; Dresp Soren; Paul Benjamin; Krahnert Ralph; Strasser Peter; Chernev Petko; Dau Holger

Mixed Ni-Fe oxides are attractive anode catalysts for efficient water splitting in solar fuels reactors. Because of conflicting past reports, the catalytically active metal redox state of the catalyst has remained under debate. Here, we report an in operando quantitative deconvolution of the charge injected into the nanostructured Ni-Fe oxyhydroxide OER catalysts or into reaction product molecules. To achieve this, we explore the oxygen evolution reaction dynamics and the individual faradaic charge efficiencies using operando differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). We further use X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) under OER conditions at the Ni and Fe K-edges of the electrocatalysts to evaluate oxidation states and local atomic structure motifs. DEMS and XAS data consistently reveal that up to 75% of the Ni centers increase their oxidation state from +2 to +3, while up to 25% arrive in the +4 state for the NiOOH catalyst under OER catalysis. The Fe centers consistently remain in the +3 state, regardless of potential and composition. For mixed Ni100-xFex catalysts, where x exceeds 9 atomic %, the faradaic efficiency of O2 sharply increases from ∼30% to 90%, suggesting that Ni atoms largely remain in the oxidation state +2 under catalytic conditions. To reconcile the apparent low level of oxidized Ni in mixed Ni-Fe catalysts, we hypothesize that a kinetic competition between the (i) metal oxidation process and the (ii) metal reduction step during O2 release may account for an insignificant accumulation of detectable high-valent metal states if the reaction rate of process (ii) outweighs that of (i). We conclude that a discussion of the superior catalytic OER activity of Ni-FeOOH electrocatalysts in terms of surface catalysis and redox-inactive metal sites likely represents an oversimplification that fails to capture essential aspects of the synergisms at highly active Ni-Fe sites.

Efficient electrocatalysts are vital for accelerating the sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Metal coordination complexes (MCCs) consisting of central metals and surrounding ligands generally possess abundant active sites owing to the rich boundaries between short-range cryst. components, making them promising candidates for tailored electrocatalysts. Herein, Ni/Fe based bimetallic MCCs with hybrid ligands are successfully constructed. With rich active sites residing in nanocrystal boundaries, bimetallic synergistic effect, and quick mass transfer derived from the nanosheet-like structure, excellent OER performance in terms of overpotential (229 mV at 10 mA cm-2) and Tafel slope (30 mV dce-1) is achieved. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) as versatile templates for prepg. transition metal compds. has received wide attention. Benefiting from their diversified spatial structure and controllable chem. constituents, they have become a research hotspot in the field of electrocatalytic water splitting. Herein, Fe2Ni-MIL-88B MOF on nickel foam (Fe2Ni MOF/NF) has been prepd. through a one-pot method growth process. Compared with Fe MOF/NF and Ni MOF/NF, the interaction between Fe3+ and Ni2+ in Fe2Ni MOF/NF accelerates the electron transfer through the oxygen of the ligand, leading to increased 3d orbital electron d. of Ni, which enhances the activity of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in alk. soln. Fe2Ni MOF/NF provides a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 at a low overpotential of 222 mV, and its Tafel slope is also very small, reaching 42.39 mV dec-1. The success of the present Fe2Ni MOF/NF catalyst is attributed to the abundant active centers, the bimetallic clusters Fe2Ni-MIL-88B, the pos. coupling effect between Ni and Fe metal ions in the MOF, and synergistic effect between the MOF and NF. Besides, Fe2Ni MOF/NF possesses excellent stability over 50 h of continuous operation, providing feasibility for com. use.

Ni-Fe (oxy)hydroxides outperform most of the non-precious metal-based catalysts towards the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Yet, the phase structure-catalytic activity correlation remains elusive because of the difficulty in synthesizing phase-pure Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides. Here, a simple room-temp. aq. soln. method has been developed to achieve phase-pure Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides with Fe content ranging from 0 to 100 at%. The Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides are simply derived from the metal-hydrazine complex by in situ transformation in alk. solns. The structural evolution and catalytic activity of the Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides are comprehensively studied to reveal the relationship between the structure and catalytic activity. The Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides present high activity at x = 0.3-0.7, and only a small overpotential of <260 mV is needed to achieve an anodic c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 in 1.0 M KOH. In addn., the catalysts exhibit high long-term working stability. It is found that their phase structure and electronic structure are related to the intrinsic activity and that the Fe/Ni ratio affects the elec. cond. of Ni1-xFex (oxy)hydroxides for optimized performance.

A review on development of industrial processes and emerging techniques for production of hydrogen from renewable and sustainable sources
Chaubey, Rashmi; Sahu, Satanand; James, Olusola O.; Maity, Sudip

A review. Hydrogen is considered as the fuel for next generation and extensive research is being pursued for search of new techniques for hydrogen prodn. from renewable sources. There is a diverse collection of hydrogen prodn. processes at their different stages of development. This review paper analyzes the industrial and emerging hydrogen prodn. technologies. These processes include steam methane reformation, partial oxidn., autothermal reforming, steam iron, plasma reforming, thermochem. water splitting and biol. processes. Till date, steam reformation of methane is the most used industrial technique and its efficiency can go up to 85%. It meets up to 50% of total hydrogen consumption in the world. Continuous research is going on to enhance prodn. yield as well as to improve the process economics. Considerable work is going on about sorption enhanced reforming and membrane reactor for this purpose. Partial oxidn. and autothermal reforming processes are the other two processes which are also used for industrial. The most sought process is the thermochem. water splitting using sunlight. Several research institutes are engaged in the development of hydrogen prodn. technologies using renewable sources. Plasma reformation and biol. processes are intensively worked out throughout the globe. The present article reviews the recent developments in industrial techniques which will lead to enhancement of hydrogen prodn. The non-conventional techniques are described in this article as emerging techniques, which are the promising approaches for hydrogen prodn. from biomass, an abundant, clean and renewable source.

Coupling NiSe2-Ni2P heterostructure nanowrinkles for highly efficient overall water splitting
Wang, Pengyan; Pu, Zonghua; Li, Wenqiang; Zhu, Jiawei; Zhang, Chengtian; Zhao, Yufeng; Mu, Shichun

Developing catalysts with high efficiency and low-cost toward overall water splitting is crit. for the sustainable energy conversion. Herein, a facile wet-chem. route followed by successive selenization and partial phosphorization treatments is presented to synthesize the heterostructure combining NiSe2 and Ni2P coupled nanowrinkles on Ni foam (NiSe2-Ni2P/NF). DFT calcn. results confirm that the NiSe2 coupled with Ni2P in NiSe2-Ni2P/NF can promote the water adsorption process, speeding up the whole catalytic kinetics for overall water splitting. Benefitting from the synergistic effects between NiSe2 and Ni2P, the optimal NiSe2-Ni2P/NF electrode exhibits excellent catalytic performances toward both oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in alk. media. Impressively, for OER such heterogeneous nanowrinkles merely require an ultralow overpotential of 220 mV to reach the c.d. of 50 mA cm-2. Moreover, when utilized as a bifunctional catalyst for overall water splitting, the c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 can be delivered at an ultralow cell voltage of 1.50 V, which is among the lowest values of current non-precious metal catalysts. This work provides a unique strategy for exploring highly efficient heterostructure catalysts toward water splitting and beyond.

The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is recognized as a key half-reaction in water electrolysis for clean hydrogen energy, which is kinetically not favored and usually requires precious metal catalysts such as IrO2 and RuO2 to reduce the overpotential. The major challenge in using non-precious metals in place of these precious metal catalysts for OER is their low efficiency and poor stability, which urgently demand new concepts and strategies to tackle this issue. Herein, we report a universal strategy to directly synthesize single layer graphene encapsulating uniform earth-abundant 3d transition-metal nanoparticles such as Fe, Co, Ni and their alloys in a confined channel of mesoporous silica. The single at. thickness of the graphene shell immensely promotes the electron transfer from the encapsulated metals to the graphene surface, which efficiently optimizes the electronic structure of the graphene surface and thereby triggers the OER activity of the inert graphene surface. We investigated a series of non-precious 3d metals encapsulated within single layer graphene, and found that the encapsulated FeNi alloy showed the best OER activity in alk. solns. with only 280 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm-2, and also possessed a high durability after 10 000 cycles. Both the activity and durability of the non-precious catalyst even exceed that of the com. IrO2 catalyst, showing great potential to replace precious metal catalysts in the OER.

Developing low cost, highly active, and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting is significant for sustainable energy systems. Herein, we report the synthesis of three-dimensional porous nickel diselenide nanowrinkles anchored on nickel foam through fabricating nickel oxalate nanosheets on nickel foam by immersion, followed by selenization under a selenium vapor atm. The hybrid material exhibits superior hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen evolution reaction performances with high activity (low overpotential), favorable kinetics, and outstanding durability in alk. solns. An overpotential of merely 166 mV is needed to reach 10 mA cm-2 for hydrogen evolution reaction and 235 mV for oxygen evolution reaction. The NiOOH species formed at the NiSe2 surface serves as the catalytic sites. Moreover, the electrolyzer only needs a cell voltage of 1.64 V to deliver 10 mA cm-2 for overall water splitting and shows excellent long-term stability (80 h at 10 mA cm-2). The unique porous nanowrinkle structure, improved elec. cond., fast charge transfer kinetics, and large electrochem. surface area are responsible for the highly active and stable electrocatalytic performance toward hydrogen evolution reaction/oxygen evolution reaction.

Efficient electrocatalysis of overall water splitting by ultrasmall NixCo3-xS4 coupled Ni3S2 nanosheet arrays
Wu, Yuanyuan; Liu, Yipu; Li, Guo-Dong; Zou, Xu; Lian, Xinran; Wang, Dejun; Sun, Lei; Asefa, Tewodros; Zou, Xiaoxin
